3-compendium/sound-engineering/01-sound-.title: 01 - Sound Engineering Introduction
3-compendium/sound-engineering/01-sound-.description:
Hello, my name is Corbin Whitton. I’m a software engineer, audio engineer, composer, producer, musician, among other things. I am so excited to share my passion for music ministry and helping you expand your skillset in this area.I’ve been working in the IT field since the late aughts (the decade from 2000-2009). I’ve owned and operated a company specialized in IT consulting, from Audio/Visual needs, to networking, server setup, cloud engineering, and hiring. I’ve worked with 10+ churches in the greater western USA (Utah, Idaho, Arizona, Wyoming, Colorado) and have provisioned several technical systems and setups to meet the very specific needs of each church. Since my background is in IT, I cater to small churches with limited resources to maximize their utilization of the tools they already have, as well as offering several powerful alternatives to costly software and hardware.Music ministry is a form of worship and outreach. It’s not simply a performance, it’s worship, it’s passion, it’s fun.The purpose of worship is to simply praise, and glorify our God. Worship can take many forms, from singing praises, to serving our community, to even monotonous daily tasks such as mowing the lawn. At it’s simplest form, worship is glorifying God. How does Music Play into it? “He put a new song in my mouth, a hymn of praise to our God. Many will see and fear the LORD and put their trust in him.” Psalm 40:3 Music, like anything we do, can be used to praise our Lord. God designed a beautiful mathematical framework for sound that allows different notes to be combined to create melodies. He created language and the ability to communicate, allowing us to create verses and lyrics. Music is just the simple combination of amplitude and pitch to produce a sound that is pleasing to the ears. Aspects of Music Ministry Musicianship - Musicians play the various different instruments to make a delightful noise. From Drums, Bass, Piano, and even vocals! Stage Hand - Stage hands are the gears that make things work, from making sure the musicians have the support they need, to replacing cables and setting up/tearing down the setup. Composing/Writing - These aspects are reserved for the most creative of us, they use the tools God gave them to match together notes, giving words to melodies. Sound Engineering - Sound engineering is the art of blending multiple inputs/outputs together and treating each audio stream as needed to make each aspect listed above perform their best. Sound is a three-dimensional air pressure wave (yes, just like water waves at the beach). We often visualize it in two-dimensions since it is more easily read and understood. Like the waves in water, sound is also a wave.
A two-dimensional representation of a wave, the distance between the top (crest) and the bottom (trough) is called amplitude and is how “loud” a sound is (usually measured in Decibels dBA). The distance between the troughs or crests is the frequency, also known as the tone, or pitch. Music theory is a system of rules, concepts, and practices that describe the structure and properties of music. It includes topics such as melody, harmony, rhythm, notation, and form, as well as the study of historical and cultural influences on music. Some of the basic elements of music theory include scales, chords, keys, intervals, and cadences. Understanding music theory can help musicians and composers better understand the relationships between different musical elements, which can in turn lead to more effective and expressive composition and performance.Certain notes sound good together because they have harmonious relationships with each other based on mathematical ratios and the physics of sound. In music theory, these relationships are described as intervals, which are the distances between two pitches. Harmonious intervals are typically small and based on simple ratios, such as the octave (2:1), the fifth (3:2), and the fourth (4:3). When these intervals are played together, the resulting combination of sound waves creates a pleasing and stable sensation for the listener. Additionally, the Western musical tradition has established certain chord progressions and harmonies over time through cultural and historical factors, which are widely recognized and used in many styles of music.

3-compendium/sound-engineering/02-captur.title: 02 - Capturing and Distributing Sound
3-compendium/sound-engineering/02-captur.description:
Instruments, microphones, cables, digital, analog, speakers. Input/output, setting up the stage, tear down Having a game plan is critical to a performance’s success. Having a plan alleviates stress, and allows for greater creativity since the bare necessities are already figured out.Some good starting questions and responses for building a plan are as follows: Who is performing? What inputs will they need access to? - Input Chart What technology are the performers using? Do I need DI boxes, microphones, MIDI network access? - Tech List Where is the sound going? Do they need it recorded or broadcasted? - Routing & Mixing How much time do the performers need to prepare? When will they be arriving? When are they doing a line test or practicing? - Schedule Prepare the space: Ensure that the stage area is clean and free of any obstacles. Move any furniture, props, or other items that may be in the way. Set up the sound system: Assemble the sound system components, including the speakers, mixer, and any other necessary equipment. Connect all cables and make sure that everything is properly powered on. Test the sound system: Perform a sound check to ensure that all components of the system are working properly. Make any necessary adjustments to volume levels or other settings. Set up the stage lighting: Assemble any stage lighting fixtures, including stands, lights, and cables. Connect the lights to power sources and make sure that they are working properly. Set up the backdrop: Unroll and hang the backdrop behind the stage. Make sure that it is properly positioned and secured in place. Arrange the stage: Place any necessary props or furniture on the stage. Make sure that everything is properly positioned and arranged in a way that is aesthetically pleasing. Check the slideshow: Start the slideshow and make sure that all images, videos and texts are being displayed correctly. Ensure that the display is working properly and make any necessary adjustments. Check the stage: Walk around the stage to make sure that everything is in place and working properly. Make any necessary adjustments or corrections. Prepare the music stand: Set up the music stand and make sure that it is in the correct position for the musicians. Prepare any other necessary equipment: Set up any other necessary equipment, such as microphones, instruments, or music stands. Make sure that everything is in its proper place and ready to use. Greet the congregation: Welcome the congregation as they arrive and help them find their seats. Make sure that everyone is comfortable and that the stage is ready for the performance. This guide should provide a basic overview of the steps involved in setting up a stage for a church on Sunday mornings. It may need to be adapted or modified to fit the specific needs and requirements of your church or venue.There are three different types of microphones that are used in live performances. Each have their own uses, strengths, and weaknesses.Dynamic microphones are the most commonly used type of microphone for live performances, and are known for their robustness and durability. They work by converting sound waves into electrical signals using a diaphragm and a coil of wire that moves within a magnetic field. Dynamic microphones are often less sensitive than other types of microphones, which makes them ideal for use in high-volume settings, as they are less likely to distort or clip the input signal.Condenser microphones, on the other hand, use a thin metal diaphragm, charged with an electrical voltage, that vibrates when it is exposed to sound waves. This vibration changes the electrical capacitance of the diaphragm, which is then converted into an electrical signal. Condenser microphones are more sensitive than dynamic microphones and are often used in studios and other professional recording environments where high levels of accuracy and detail are required. Since condenser microphones are charged with an electrical voltage, external power is needed to make them function, known as Phantom Power, also denoted as +48v, which injects the power into the XLR cable.A compressor microphone is a type of condenser microphone that has an internal compressor built-in. The compressor circuit reduces the dynamic range of the microphone, which helps to reduce the volume of loud sounds and increase the volume of soft sounds. This makes compressor microphones ideal for use in situations where there are significant variations in the volume of the sound being captured, as it helps to ensure that the output signal is consistent and balanced. Since compressor microphones are condenser microphones, external power is needed to make them function, known as Phantom Power, also denoted as +48v, which injects the power into the XLR cable.Microphone Placement Place microphones close to the source: Placing microphones close to the source of sound (e.g. an instrument or singer) Use directional microphones: Directional microphones (e.g. cardioid, supercardioid, and hypercardioid) can be used to capture sound from a specific direction and rejecting sound from other directions. Avoid pointing multiple microphones at the same source: Pointing multiple microphones at the same source can lead to phase cancellations and the comb filtering effect. To avoid this, try to use only one microphone or place multiple microphones at different angles to the source. If you are amplifying a choir, and have no choice but to use multiple microphones, see the 3:1 rule. Use microphone isolation techniques: Microphone isolation techniques (e.g. gobos, screens, and foam shields) can help to reduce the pickup of sound from other sources Experiment with microphone placement: The best microphone placement will vary depending on the specific situation, so it's important to experiment with different microphone placement techniques to find the best results. Pay attention to factors such as distance, angle, and orientation to the source, and be prepared to make adjustments as needed. If you’re struggling picking up the deeper, richer, low ends of a sound using a microphone, consider moving the microphone much closer to the source. As low-frequency sounds are dispersed much more easily.
There are a lot of different mediums that sound can be moved from one place to another. The most used audio cables, and likely, the ones you’re most familiar with is RCA, XLR, TS/TRS, and USB cables. There are two different types of cables, digital and analog. Analog cables carry the actual noise signal, while digital cables carry bits (1s or 0s) that approximate and represent the audio signal. When and matching audio cables, converters such as Direct Injection (DI) boxes often need to be used to convert, normalize, balance, and translate one signal to another.For longer cable runs, especially parallel cables, balanced cables are far superior. This is because balanced cables have three wires, one wire carries the signal, one wire carries the same signal but with its polarity reversed so the signals cancel out (like adding +4 and -4 equals 0), and a ground wire to help shield against interference. Audio gear would just need to flip the polarity of one of the signal wires to get sound.Unbalanced cables, on the other hand have just two wires, a signal wire that carries the sound, and a ground wire. With only one signal wire, an unbalanced cable is far more susceptible to interference (can be a hum or static). Unbalanced cables are not a good idea if multiple cables are going to be ran close together.You can use a DI (direct injection) box to convert an unbalanced cable like a TS cable to a balanced cable like XLR
Pictured is a Direct Injection (DI) box. This is a great way to connect instruments with a TS/TRS cable to a soundboard using an XLR cable. A DI box removes the noise (static) before handing the signal to the XLR cable. If there’s still noise, enable the -15db pad.

Balanced or Unbalanced? Which should I choose?

3-compendium/sound-engineering/03-introd.title: 03 - Introduction to Mixing
3-compendium/sound-engineering/03-introd.description:
There are 5 different types of Mixing and Sound engineering, each type has a slightly different process and purpose. It is advised to have a dedicated engineer for each position a production needs.
Recording Engineer These engineers need to know their way around a mixing console, monitoring sound levels, audio equalization, routing, and need to work closely with musicians to properly capture their performance. They usually work in a recording studio to capture a performance before the mixing engineer has a chance to work with the audio.
Mixing Engineer These engineers take a recording, apply filters, effects, and audio processing to create
Mastering Engineer
Live Sound Engineer/Front-of-House Engineer
Multimedia Engineer
A sound console, also known as a mixing console or mixer, is a device used to control the levels, processing, and routing of audio signals. It is an essential component in live sound reinforcement, recording studios, and broadcasting.
Scribble Strip: A scribble strip is a small label or screen that is located above or below each channel fader on a sound console. The purpose of the scribble strip is to display information about the channel and its source, such as the name of the microphone or instrument connected to the channel, and to help the sound engineer identify and manage individual channels more easily. Some digital sound consoles also allow the user to customize the scribble strip by entering custom labels or choosing from pre-defined options, making it even more useful for managing complex sound setups. If that is unavailable, never underestimate a square of masking tape and a Sharpie.
Faders: Faders are sliding controls that adjust the volume level of a particular channel or group of channels. They are typically found in the channel strip section of a sound console and are usually positioned vertically.
Mute and Solo buttons: Mute buttons are used to temporarily turn off the audio signal of a particular channel, while solo buttons are used to temporarily isolate and listen to a single channel while muting all others.
Selecting a channel: To select a channel on a sound console, you usually have to press a button or flip a switch that corresponds to that channel. Some sound consoles also have a bank of channel selector buttons, allowing you to quickly switch between different groups of channels.
Channel gain: Channel gain is the first step in the signal processing chain in a sound console and refers to the adjustment of the level of an individual channel before it is mixed with other channels. It is used to control the overall volume of a specific audio source and is often represented by a rotary knob or a fader on the channel strip.
In summary, a sound console is a complex device that enables sound engineers and musicians to control, process, and mix multiple audio signals. Understanding the basic components and functions of a sound console is important for anyone working in the field of audio production.

3-compendium/sound-engineering/04-making.title: 04 - Making Audio Sound Good
3-compendium/sound-engineering/04-making.description:
A sound console typically includes a variety of signal processing tools to shape and manipulate the sound of individual audio channels or groups of channels. Here is an overview of some common audio processing tools and effects:
Low cut/high pass filter: A low cut (or high pass) filter is a type of frequency filter that allows frequencies above (or below) a certain cutoff frequency to pass through while reducing or cutting frequencies below (or above) the cutoff. This is useful for removing unwanted low-frequency rumble or high-frequency hiss.
High cut/low pass filter: A high cut (or low pass) filter is the opposite of a low cut filter, allowing frequencies below (or above) a certain cutoff frequency to pass through while reducing or cutting frequencies above (or below) the cutoff.
Gate: A gate is a dynamic processing tool that opens or closes to allow or suppress audio signals below a certain threshold. Gates are commonly used to control noise or eliminate unwanted background noise.
Compressor: A compressor is a dynamic processing tool that reduces the dynamic range of a signal by automatically reducing the volume of loud passages and increasing the volume of quiet passages. This is useful for balancing levels and preventing audio signals from clipping or becoming too loud.
EQ: EQ (equalization) is the process of adjusting the balance between different frequency components within an audio signal. This can be used to enhance or reduce specific frequencies to shape the tonal quality of a sound.
Effects: Effects are processing tools used to add special characteristics to audio signals. Some common effects include: Suboctaver: A suboctaver effect generates a lower pitch version of the input audio signal. Vocoder: A vocoder effect modulates the spectrum of one signal (typically a vocal input) using another signal (typically a synthesizer).
Chorus: A chorus effect creates a doubling effect by combining a delayed and pitch-modulated version of the input signal with the original.
Amp simulation: An amp simulation effect models the sound of a guitar or bass amplifier.
Phaser: A phaser effect creates a sweeping, phase-shifted version of the input signal.
Reverb: Reverb creates the impression of an acoustic space by adding a dense, decaying tail of echoes to the original sound.
Delay: Delay creates a repetition of the input signal at a delayed time interval. Insert effects: Insert effects are processing tools that are applied to individual channels within a sound console. These effects are typically applied to the channel before it is mixed with other channels.
Bus effects: Bus effects are processing tools that are applied to groups of channels within a sound console. For example, you might use a bus effect to process a group of drum channels before they are mixed together.
Side-chain effects: Side-chain effects use the level of one audio signal (the sidechain signal) to control the processing of another audio signal (the main signal). A common example of a side-chain effect is a ducking effect, where the level of the main signal is reduced whenever the sidechain signal reaches a certain threshold.
3-compendium/sound-engineering/04-making.sourcePath: 3 - Compendium/Sound Engineering/04 - Making Audio Sound Good.md

3-compendium/sound-engineering/05-routin.title: 05 - Routing, and Advanced Techniques
3-compendium/sound-engineering/05-routin.description:
In a digital mixer, routing refers to the process of sending audio signals from one place to another within the mixer. The routing capabilities of a digital mixer can be quite complex and flexible, allowing for a wide range of signal processing and mixing options. Busses: Busses are virtual pathways within a digital mixer that allow audio signals to be combined and processed together. For example, you might use a bus to combine several channels of audio into a single stereo mix. Busses can be assigned to outputs such as speakers or headphones, or to processing tools such as effects. Matrices: Matrices are similar to busses, but allow for more complex signal routing options. With a matrix, you can route any channel or bus to any output or processing tool within the mixer. This can be useful for creating custom monitor mixes or for routing signals to multiple processing tools. DCAs (Digitally Controlled Amplifiers): DCAs are a type of group processing that allow you to control the level of multiple channels or busses with a single control. For example, you might use a DCA to control the level of all drum channels in a mix. DCAs can be especially useful in live sound reinforcement, where you need to make quick and accurate level adjustments to multiple channels at once. In summary, routing in a digital mixer involves the assignment of audio signals to various pathways within the mixer, allowing you to control and process the signals as needed. Busses, matrices, and DCAs are some of the tools that can be used to control and manipulate the routing of audio signals in a digital mixer.Okay, this one's a bit advanced, but if you understand a few concepts about Psycho-acoustics (How music affects human psychology), you can easily make music that people can connect with.If you want to make music that people connect with, the first thing you need to know is how lower frequencies affect how people perceive music. If you've looked at the average human's frequency response curve, there's a sharp drop off below anything under 100hz. For the most part, anything under that threshold starts to become "percusive", it's sound that you can feel more than hear. Because of that, you can curate sound that feels like it has energy, it can be used to evoke strong emotional feelings in humans. Mid-bass (about 50-80hz) feels punchy, and can be felt in your head. Low-bass (about 30-50hz) can be felt in the chest and is described as "fullness" or as the "bass body". Ultra-low-bass (<25hz) creates more of a pulsating feeling, and is tough to achieve with conventional sub-woofers making some resort to rotary sub-woofers.This one's a weird one that often bites sound engineers in the butt, but listening to music over and over slowly accustoms people to what that music sounds like. Most people with mild tinnitus can tune it out so it doesn't bother them, in the same way, listening to audio that sounds bad becomes the baseline after a while. You can use this knowledge in two ways, you can use it to make your audio sound better by taking breaks where you listen to something else so you can get a fresh set of ears on your sound, or you can use it to make any audience perceive that the performance is otherworldly by controlling what their baseline is. Yes, I'm talking about making the pre-recorded music often played in-between or before performances sound terrible; slap the most aggressive EQ on it and remove all the highs and lows, experiment with a wonky compressor to remove all the dynamics, so long as it's bad, your live show will sound great.You can use Equal Loudness - Fletcher-Munson Curves to your advantage to mix in a way that sounds full and LOUD without making it painful to be in the room. As you noticed, our ears can take more lower end and high pitched sounds than that that 3k-5khz range. Which means you can push those sounds to be louder using your EQ, and trim out a bit of that mid range frequencies that hurt people's ears. Microphone placement: Experiment with different microphone placement techniques to find the best sound for each instrument or performer. Pay attention to factors such as distance, angle, and orientation to the source. Dynamic range compression: Use dynamic range compression to control the difference between the loudest and softest sounds in a mix. This can help to prevent distortion and ensure that the audio remains at a consistent level. Equalization: Use equalization (EQ) to shape the tone of individual sounds in a mix. For example, you can use high-pass filters to remove low-frequency rumble or boost high frequencies to add clarity. Reverb: Add reverb to create a sense of space and depth in a mix. Experiment with different reverb types and settings to find the best sound for each situation. Delay: Use delay to create a sense of spaciousness and depth in a mix. Experiment with different delay times and feedback levels to find the best sound for each situation. Automation: Use automation to make precise, repeatable changes to the levels and settings of individual sounds in a mix. For example, you can use automation to gradually bring up the volume of a guitar solo or fade out a vocal track. Stereo imaging: Use stereo imaging techniques to create a wider, more spacious soundstage. Experiment with panning, delay, and reverb to find the best sound for each situation. Sidechain compression: Use sidechain compression to control the level of one sound in relation to another. For example, you can use sidechain compression to reduce the volume of a bass line whenever a kick drum hits. Don’t be afraid to experiment. You will only succeed by the same measure you’re willing to fail.
EQ Problems - Bobby Owsinski 200Hz (Mud) – Too much can cause the track or the mix to sound muddy or boomy, while not enough of it can make it sound thin. It’s a fine line, but many times mixers err on the side of too much and end up with a track that’s too thick that clutters up the mix. 300 to 500Hz (Boxy) – Too much of this frequency area results in the dreaded “boxiness” sound, or if you’re listening to a floor tom or kick, the “beach ball” effect. It’s also a spot that some less expensive microphones (especially dynamics) tend to emphasize, which is why many mixers almost automatically cut a a few dB of this area out of the kick drum during the mix. 800Hz (Walmart) – Too much in this area results in what’s sometimes known as the “Walmart” sound, meaning that it sounds like a cheap stereo purchased in a department store. Try it for yourself – get a cheap pair of computer speakers and you’ll find that 800Hz is what you’ll mostly hear. Obviously, too much of this frequency range is not a good thing. 1k to 1.5kHz (Nasal) – This is the nasal range of the frequency spectrum and, as the name suggests, too much results in a vocalist that sounds like she’s singing through her nose. Once again this is primarily a microphone problem in that it’s poorly matched to the vocalist, but notching a bit out during the mix can fix it. 4kHz to 6kHz (Presence) – This frequency range is frequently underutilized during the mix, resulting in a track that lacks definition. Without it, things tend to sound dull, but too much can make the track sound thin or, in the case of a vocal, sibilant. 10kHz+ (Air) – Another widely overlooked frequency band, this provides clarity and adds a certain “realness” to the track. Many vintage mics have a lot of the air frequencies, which is why we prize them for their sound. The Maag Audio EQ4P has a special “Air Band” designed to provide those frequencies with a minimum of phase shift, but you can dial it in other equalizers as well. Train your ears! These are just a few examples of advanced sound engineering techniques that you can use to enhance the audio quality of your live events and recordings. Keep in mind that each technique requires a different skill set and level of expertise, so it's important to experiment and practice to find the best results.If you want to make a wonderful sounding mix, I highly suggest looking at Bobby Owsinski’s work. He has several handbooks, webinars, and guides to help you create good sounding music.The 3:1 rule is a guideline for microphone placement that can help to reduce the likelihood of phase cancellations and the comb filtering effect. The rule states that the distance between two microphones should be at least three times the distance between each microphone and the source of sound.For example, if you're placing a microphone 1 foot away from a singer, the other microphone should be at least 3 feet away from both the singer and the first microphone. This distance helps to reduce the likelihood of phase cancellations and the comb filtering effect, which can occur when two microphones are picking up sound from the same source at different levels or times.By following the 3:1 rule, you can help to ensure that the sound captured by each microphone is as distinct as possible, reducing the likelihood of phase cancellations and the comb filtering effect. Keep in mind that this is just a general guideline, and the best microphone placement will vary depending on the specific situation.The inverse square law states that the intensity (or sound pressure level) of a point source decreases as the distance from the source increases. The intensity of the sound is proportional to the inverse of the square of the distance. Mathematically, this can be represented as: where is the intensity of the sound, is the power of the source, pi is the mathematical constant (approximately equal to 3.14), and is the distance from the source.This means that as the distance from the source increases, the intensity of the sound decreases at a rate proportional to the inverse of the square of the distance. For example, if the distance from the source is doubled, the intensity of the sound will decrease to one-fourth of its original level.The inverse square law is a fundamental principle of acoustics and applies to all types of sound sources, including speakers, microphones, and other sound-emitting devices. Understanding this law is important for sound engineers, as it helps to predict how the intensity of sound will change based on the distance from the source, and to make informed decisions about microphone placement, speaker placement, and other aspects of sound reinforcement.This one's not as important in live environments, but if one of your inputs sound "thin" in the mix, and you want to make it sound like it's coming from a wider space, introduce a ~30ms delay in one of your stereo channels to make it sound wider. For Mono mixes, the Haas effect is a bit harder to pull off, but you can always duplicate the channel and pan one right, and the other left, and introduce a delay. You might have to tweak the timing so you don't get weird "chorus-like" artifacts or strange phase interactions.High-frequencies should be panned "wider" than lower frequencies because higher frequencies are more easily blocked by the head, which is why wide panned lower frequencies sound weird when wearing headphones.If you're struggling to find a way to get an instrument that don't have higher frequencies such as a Bass guitar to sound louder, try adding saturation to the lower-frequency sounds to create higher-frequency harmonics. This helps it sound fuller and more defined especially if the speakers are having a hard time replicating that low-frequency of a sound.Okay. This is just a rant on how important it is to know how the human ear perceives sound at different volumes. Yes, I'm talking about Fletcher-Munson curves; know them, understand them, use them. It should be noted that the red lines mean that the sound has to be that loud to hear it. and how loud it can be until it starts to cause pain. You can use that knowlege to make music LOUD
Toss an EQ on your reverb and delay effects and trim out the higher ends to simulate the loss of higher frequencies as sound travels further. It's a subtle, organic, and ethically-sourced way to make your mixes sound more believable.It's pretty simple to understand that LOUD sounds make small sounds disappear. Mixing is a delicate balance to make every instrument and vocalist audible and blend together seamlessly. It's simple to just "turn up" the instrument that's quiet, but sometimes, it needs to be more subtle, sometimes you can just scoop out the frequencies of the acoustic guitar that's already covered by the electric guitar. You can just carve out frequency for different instruments to make each of them stand out.

headers.heading: How to make nearly ANY live music sound GREAT
Equal Perceived Loudness and Fletcher-Munson Curves
Make Reverb and Delay sound Natural

3-compendium/sound-engineering/basic-fes.title: Basic Festival Setup
3-compendium/sound-engineering/basic-fes.description:
Green: Vocalist (High Chance of Feedback)
Red: Instrument (Medium Chance of Feedback)
Yellow: Originating from a computer (No Chance of feedback)
Purple: Speaker with a headset microphone (Important, should take priority over Teal, high chance of feedback)
Teal: Floating speaker with a handheld microphone (High Chance of Feedback)
Black: Unused/Standby Yellow: Originating from a computer
Black: Unused/Standby
Orange: Destined to Be a direct output
Green: Meant for monitoring White: Multiple groups
Black: Unused/Standby
Other: Follows other coloring standards. All IEM stage monitors should be tapped pre-mute, post-gain.
All stage wedge monitors should be tapped post-mute, pre-eq. Plan on arriving early enough to setup the stage for the performers so sound-check can start as soon as they arrive. Ensure the following items are done: Sound system is on, and ready (Any outputs should be muted at this point)
Stage is laid out as specified in the design plan
Each performer has any DI boxes, cables, or power that they need to perform.
Take a note how everything is plugged into the system, and if any routing changes needed to happen (for example, if the guitarist is plugged into 16, and was rerouted to appear in channel 5)
All monitoring equipment is connected, and in working order.
Gaff down any cords that may become a tripping hazard.
If there are central crew coms, verify that everyone can hear you clearly, and you can hear coordinators clearly.
Make a note on any borrowed equipment and who it belongs to.
Unmute main speakers last, ensuring each input is muted before sound check. Sound check: Ensure each instrument and input is working and can be heard all the way through its desired output. This includes any media or lighting sends.
Pre-event planning: While the performers get ready for the event, ensure EQs, dynamics, and effects sound well. Take notes on the following items: Timeline and order of the events
Important cues for each segment of the event
If there's music or speaking, take notes on who's leading
If additional dynamics are needed, such as changing out EQs, effects, or fader variations, take a note of what and when.
Run through an overview of your notes with your Point-of-contact.
Understand if any digital control systems are set up and how they'll affect you (such as MIDI, OSC, USB, HTTP APIs, etc)
Ensure any recording devices are armed and ready to record
Ensure all stage monitors are at an acceptable level while minimizing the chance of feedback.
Ensure to check with ALL performers if they have any comments, questions, or concerns regarding their sound and incorporate criticism early
Prepare all speaker microphones with fresh batteries, and ensure speakers have been briefed on how to use a microphone, what to do if it's muted, how to unmute, etc (Though, locking mics is preferred). Ensure any speakers wearing a headset microphone has it on correctly (not bending the wires too much), and the tip of the lavalier microphone is at the corner of their mouth, but not touching their face; make sure they know not to touch it.
Before the actual event, check battery levels of all microphones, and ensure that they'll last the entire performance.
If you're using a digital mixer, ensure all scene configurations have been saved, backed up internally (and externally if possible).
Have a quick briefing with your backstage team to see if there's anything that you missed in your notes. Actual Event: While the event happens, ensure any necessary recordings are started
Post-event Immediately mute all inputs that are not desired to be heard.
Ensure any recordings have been stopped and delivered to the POC or designee.
Debrief with the POC to see if there was anything that could have gone better or that worked well.
Debrief with the behind-the-stage team and see if there was anything that could have gone better or that worked well. Strike the stage, ensuring all sound equipment is returned how you found it or where it's supposed to go.
Ensure all borrowed equipment is returned promptly to its owner.
Finally, fade out any remaining audio, ending with the mains muted. Then turn off the sound system in the proper order.
Do one final walk-through to ensure everything's put away, that all borrowed items are returned, that everything's off
Collect all your things including monitoring equipment, any microphones or cables lent for the event.

0-meta/indices/philosophy.html.description:

3-compendium/challenging-modernity.html.title: Challenging Modernity
3-compendium/challenging-modernity.html.description: #ideals #philosophy Modern life often flattens or dilutes human experience. Philosophers critique the way modernity prioritizes convenience, consumption, and distraction over depth. Nietzsche’s “last man” represents the complacent modern individual, avoiding discomfort or greatness: “What is love? What is creation? What is longing? What is a star?” — thus asks the last man and blinks. Heidegger critiques the modern obsession with technology and distraction, which leads to a loss of authentic being. He describes this as a state of “forgetfulness of Being”. Herbert Marcuse and the Frankfurt School argue that mass culture under capitalism turns individuals into passive consumers, dulling their capacity for critical reflection. Ideals, then, serve as a counterforce — calling us back to depth, awareness, and meaningful values.

3-compendium/confronting-unavoidable-tru.title: Confronting Unavoidable Truths
3-compendium/confronting-unavoidable-tru.description:
#ideals #philosophy Many philosophical traditions emphasize the importance of confronting deep, often unsettling truths about existence: mortality, meaninglessness, freedom, or suffering. Existentialists like Jean-Paul Sartre and Albert Camus argue that life presents us with absurd or tragic realities that cannot be ignored. Sartre: “Man is nothing else but what he makes of himself.” Camus: “There is but one truly serious philosophical problem, and that is suicide.” (i.e., the question of meaning) Nietzsche challenges us to face the “abyss” of meaninglessness and respond with creative power. “He who has a why to live can bear almost any how.” These thinkers argue that ideals are born from our confrontation with reality — not from avoiding it.
Philosophy
Ideals

3-compendium/moral-awakening.html.title: Moral Awakening
3-compendium/moral-awakening.html.description: #moral-transformation #philosophy Like a religious conversion or existential crisis, moral awakening is sudden and transformative. Simone Weil describes attention as the key to moral life: *“The capacity to give one’s attention to a sufferer… is almost a miracle.”

3-compendium/nicomachean-ethics.html.title: Nicomachean Ethics
3-compendium/nicomachean-ethics.html.description:
Aristotle investigates the highest human good:
Eudaimonia — often translated as happiness, flourishing, or living well.
"Every art and every inquiry... aims at some good." (Book I) The ultimate end of human life.
Not momentary pleasure, wealth, or honor.
Achieved through rational activity in accordance with virtue. "Happiness is an activity of soul in accordance with virtue." (I.7) Two types: Moral virtues: acquired by habit (e.g. courage, temperance).
Intellectual virtues: developed through teaching (e.g. wisdom, understanding). "We become just by doing just acts." (II.1) Virtue is the mean between two vices: one of excess, one of deficiency.
Example: Courage lies between cowardice and recklessness. "Virtue... is a mean between two vices." (II.6) Enables sound moral judgment.
Not just knowing what is good, but knowing how to act well. "It is impossible to be good in the full sense without practical wisdom." (VI.13) Essential to the good life. Three kinds: Friendships of utility
Friendships of pleasure
Friendships of virtue (the highest) "Without friends no one would choose to live, though he had all other goods." (VIII.1) Highest form of happiness.
Life of reason and philosophical reflection. "The activity of reason... is the highest." (X.7)
A good life is a life of rational virtue, lived in community, guided by practical wisdom, and fulfilled through contemplation.

3-compendium/nietzsche’s-internal-strugg.title: Nietzsche’s Internal Struggle
3-compendium/nietzsche’s-internal-strugg.description: #inner-conflict #morality #philosophy Nietzsche frames life as a struggle between opposing forces: Apollo (order, reason) and Dionysus (chaos, instinct). Overcoming internal division is key to becoming the “overman” (Übermensch), a being who creates new values. Moral growth often begins in inner conflict — a theme across philosophical traditions.

3-compendium/pessimistic-philosophy.html.title: Pessimistic Philosophy
3-compendium/pessimistic-philosophy.html.description:
Pessimistic philosophy holds that life is fundamentally marked by suffering, frustration, and lack, and that happiness is either unattainable or fleeting. “Life is suffering.” – Common thread across pessimistic thought It is not nihilism or despair for its own sake, but a confrontation with the painful structure of existence, often with ethical or contemplative aims. Will is the blind, irrational force behind all life. Desire leads to suffering. Once satisfied, it gives way to boredom, then new desire. The world is not rational or moral; it just is. “Life swings like a pendulum backward and forward between pain and boredom.” – The World as Will and Representation Escape: Through art, asceticism, and compassion — temporary or partial relief from the will. Initially influenced by Schopenhauer but broke away. Acknowledged life’s suffering but rejected resignation. Proposed affirmation of life through strength, creativity, and self-overcoming. “To live is to suffer, to survive is to find some meaning in the suffering.” – Thus Spoke Zarathustra (paraphrased) Though not a pessimist in the strict sense, he grappled deeply with pessimism’s challenge. Extreme form of philosophical pessimism. Views life as absurd, painful, and void of purpose. Embraces contradiction and poetic despair. “It is not worth the bother of killing yourself, since you always kill yourself too late.” – The Trouble with Being Born Suffering is central to human existence. Desire leads to dissatisfaction. No ultimate meaning can be found in the world. Responses vary: Schopenhauer: renounce desire. Nietzsche: affirm existence despite it. Cioran: express existential irony or detachment. Pessimistic philosophy does not offer easy hope. Instead, it calls for clarity: to see life without illusion, and either withdraw from its demands or rise above them creatively. Philosophy
Nihilism

3-compendium/plato's-divided-self.html.title: Plato's Divided Self
3-compendium/plato's-divided-self.html.description: #inner-conflict #morality #philosophy (Plato)** In Plato’s Republic, the soul is divided into: Rational (reason), Spirited (will/emotion), Appetitive (desire). Justice is achieved when these parts are in harmony, with reason guiding the whole. The life of the just man is more profitable than that of the unjust. Plato

3-compendium/stoicism.html.title: Stoicism
3-compendium/stoicism.html.description:
Stoicism is a practical philosophy aimed at achieving inner peace through virtue and rational living. It teaches that we must distinguish between what we can control and what we cannot, and align our will with nature. “A rational being’s highest good is reason.” – Epictetus At the heart of Stoic ethics is the clear distinction: In our control: Our beliefs Our judgments Our desires and actions Not in our control: Other people Outcomes Fame, fortune, health, death “Some things are up to us and some are not.” – Enchiridion 1 Peace comes from focusing only on what we can govern — our own minds.For Stoics, virtue — composed of wisdom, courage, justice, and temperance — is the sole source of a good life. Everything else (pleasure, pain, wealth, poverty) is indifferent in moral terms. “If you seek truth, you will not seek victory by dishonorable means.” – Epictetus Virtue is practiced moment to moment, by reasoning well and acting with integrity, regardless of circumstance.To live well is to live in harmony with: Human nature: rational and social Cosmic nature: ordered but indifferent to our preferences This means accepting fate (the Stoic logos) without resistance, and fulfilling your role in life with excellence. “Don’t demand that things happen as you wish, but wish that they happen as they do, and your life will go smoothly.” – Enchiridion 8 Stoicism does not reject emotion, but seeks freedom from passions — destructive emotions based on faulty judgments. We suffer not from events, but from our interpretation of them. “Men are disturbed not by things, but by the views which they take of them.” – Epictetus Training the mind through reflection, journaling, and self-awareness is essential. Born a slave in Phrygia, freed in Rome. Taught that philosophy is training for the soul, not abstract theory. Emphasized: Moral responsibility Detachment from externals Inner freedom through discipline His Discourses and Enchiridion are clear, practical, and uncompromising. “No one is free who is not master of himself.” – Discourses Like Aristotle, Stoics sought eudaimonia (human flourishing), but grounded it entirely in moral character. Freedom, joy, and tranquility are side effects of a virtuous and rational life, not ends in themselves.Stoicism is not withdrawal from life, but full engagement with it — guided by reason, shaped by virtue, and rooted in acceptance. As Epictetus reminds us, peace is always within reach — if we learn to govern ourselves. “You may be unconquerable, if you enter into no combat in which it is not in your power to conquer.” – Enchiridion 19 Philosophy
Nicomachean Ethics

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
